revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{History of Fiji}} The [[Fiji]]an '''constitutional crisis of 2009''' began on Friday, 10 April 2009. [[President of Fiji|Fijian President]] [[Josefa Iloilo|Ratu Josefa Iloilo]] announced on a nationwide radio broadcast that he was abrogating the [[1997 Constitution of Fiji|Constitution of Fiji]]. He dismissed all judges and constitutional appointees and assumed all [[governance]] in the country after the [[Court of Appeal of Fiji|Court of Appeal]] ruled that the government of Prime Minister [[Frank Bainimarama]] was illegal.<ref name=ta>{{cite news |title=Fijian president Ratu Josefa Iloilo abolishes constitution, sacks judiciary and assumes power |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,24897,25316239-601,00.html|agency=[[Australian Associated Press]]|work=The Australian|date=10 April 2009 |accessdate=10 April 2009}}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Iloilo reinstalled Bainimarama as PM and his Cabinet members to their positions. He also instituted emergency rule which increased police powers and allowed media censorship.
==Background== {{Main article|2006 Fijian coup d'état}} On Thursday, 9 April 2009, the [[Court of Appeal of Fiji|Court of Appeal]], the second highest in [[Fiji]], issued a [[court ruling|ruling]] stating the illegality of the [[2006 Fijian coup d'état]], which removed the government of [[Laisenia Qarase]] from power, replacing it with [[military dictatorship|military rule]].<ref name=ta/> The court also called the interim government established in January 2007 "invalid."<ref name=tahitip>{{cite news|title=Fiji under New Legal Order and new Head of State |url=http://www.tahitipresse.pf/index.cfm?snav=see&presse=27226&lang=2 |work=[[Tahitpresse]] |date=10 April 2009 |accessdate=10 April 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090416222059/http://www.tahitipresse.pf/index.cfm?snav=see&presse=27226&lang=2 |archivedate=16 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> The ruling legally dissolved the current parliament.<ref name=tahitip/>
The Court of Appeals ordered President Iloilo to appoint a "distinguished person" to act as a caretaker Prime Minister and oversee the dissolution of parliament.<ref name=tahitip/> The court further ordered that Iloilo was forbidden from appointing either current Prime Minister [[Frank Bainimarama]] or former Prime Minister Laisenia Qarase as the caretaker.<ref name=tahitip/>
The Court of Appeals ruling "prompted" the Prime Minister to step down from power.<ref name=ta/> Iloilo had sworn Bainimarama into office in January 2007. Bainimarama immediately reverted to his former position as [[Republic of Fiji Military Forces|army]] [[commander]].<ref name=tahitip/> His cabinet also resigned after the court's ruling.<ref name=tahitip/>
==Suspension of Constitution== President Iloilo issued a statement the following day saying, "I hereby confirm I have abrogated the [[1997 Constitution of Fiji|1997 constitution]] and appointed myself as [[head of state]] in the new order."<ref name=ta/> Iloilo immediately assumed all political power in the country.<ref name=ta/>
In his statement, Iloilo fired the Fijian [[judiciary]] and nullified all judicial appointments.<ref name=ta/> He stated that "All judicial appointments are no longer in place. New appointments are to be made for judges, [[magistrate]]s and other [[judicial officer]]s. I will soon be inviting suitable individuals to join or rejoin the bench under the new order."<ref name=tahitip/> He also decreed that all existing laws would remain in place.<ref>[http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=118899 New Order], Fiji Times Online, 11 April 2009</ref>
Iloilo announced that Fiji would hold democratic elections in September 2014 "at the latest."<ref name=tahitip/> He also promised to appoint an [[interim]] prime minister.<ref name=ta/> To that end, he issued a decree which allowed him to appoint a Prime Minister by decree.<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0411/breaking13.htm Fiji appoints coup leader as PM], The Irish Times, 11 April 2009</ref> Parliament had not met since the 2006 coup.<ref>[http://www.pgaction.org/uploadedfiles/ICC%20Calendar%202008-2009%20_8-1-08_.pdf Parliamentary Campaign for the Universality and Effectiveness of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (PGA ICC Campaign 2008–2009)], Parliamentarians for Global Action, 18 July 2008</ref> He subsequently re-appointed Frank Bainimarama as the "new" Interim prime minister.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/04/11/2540837.htm?section=world Bainimarama sworn in again as Fiji PM], Sean Dorney, ABC, 11 April 2009. Retrieved 1 June 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hj1kDQNm?url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/04/11/2540837.htm?section%3Dworld Archived] 22 June 2009.</ref> Bainimarama later reinstalled all of his previous Cabinet members to their same positions.<ref name= "Xinhua">[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-04/11/content_11169754.htm Banimarama: Fiji to hold general elections by Sept. 2014], Xinhua News Agency, 11 April 2009</ref> In a 17 April speech to civil servants Bainimarama announced that his government was not an interim one and that elections would not be held before 2014: "A new Legal Order means there is no longer the old. There is no need to speculate as to what happened, how it happened, what should have happened or what should not have happened. What is, is now, and the future."<ref name="Field">{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/2341423/Bainimarama-says-he-is-the-future |title=Bainimarama says he is the future |author=Field, Michael |date=17 April 2009 |work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=18 September 2011}}</ref> Iloilo's announcement of a new judiciary clarified that the abrogation of the constitution would not be subject to any judicial review.<ref>[http://australianetworknews.com/stories/200904/2545985.htm?desktop Fiji to revive courts within days] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707191152/http://australianetworknews.com/stories/200904/2545985.htm?desktop |date=7 July 2011 }}, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, 17 April 2009</ref>
Fiji was placed under a "Public Emergency Regulation", putting the country under emergency rule for 30 days.<ref name= "Xinhua" /> This regulation gave the police the right "to control the movement of people" and to stop any broadcast or publication it deemed "could cause disorder, promote disaffection or public alarm or undermine the government or state of Fiji".<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/national/fiji-may-face-economic-sanctions-says-canberra-20090411-a3hd.html?page=2 Fiji may face economic sanctions, says Canberra], Josh Gordon, The Age, 12 April 2009</ref> On some key roads, police had established roadblocks but the military was not involved.<ref>[http://news.brisbanetimes.com.au/breaking-news-world/fiji-military-chief-reappointed-as-pm-20090411-a33m.html Fiji military chief reappointed as PM], Pita Ligaiula, Brisbane Times, 11 April 2009</ref> Police "postponed" any assemblies of more than 100 people and revoked permits already issued including the annual meeting of the Fiji Nursing Association and perhaps the elections of the Fiji Teachers Union.<ref>[http://www.fijilive.com/news_new/index.php/news/show_news/15257 Public meetings postponed, say police] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090419182015/http://www.fijilive.com/news_new/index.php/news/show_news/15257 |date=19 April 2009 }}, Fijilive, 16 April 2009</ref> In July, the annual Methodist general meeting was not given a permit. Several Methodist Church leaders and a village high chief who was providing space for the meeting were arrested and released on condition that they not appear in public.<ref>[http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2009/julyweb-only/130-2.0.html Fiji Bans Massive Methodist Hymn-Sing], Christianity Today, 31 July 2009</ref><ref name="TVNZ_2870943">{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/world-news/church-challenges-fiji-regime-s-power-2870943 |title=Church challenges Fiji regime's power |date=25 July 2009 |work=[[One News (New Zealand)|ONE News]] |accessdate=18 September 2011}}</ref> The Methodist annual meeting scheduled for August was later cancelled by church leadership.
All positions established under the 1997 Constitution were held to be vacant. In the following days, some of these office holders were reinstalled into the same offices, including the Commissioner of Police, the Commissioner of Prisons, the Commander of the RFMF, the Solicitor General.<ref name="RNZI_45963">{{cite web |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=45963 |title=Fiji Reserve Bank gets new governor |date=15 April 2009 |work=[[Radio New Zealand International]] |accessdate=18 September 2011}}</ref> Others were not reappointed as in the case of the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Fiji who was replaced by the Deputy Governor. Other positions were not immediately refilled, such as the courts, the Constitutional Offices Commission, the Judicial Service Commission, the Disciplined Services Commission and the Human Rights Commission.<ref>[http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=119288 3 commissions not reinstated], Fiji Times, 16 April 2009</ref><ref>[http://in.news.yahoo.com/43/20090414/902/twl-fiji-military-government-tightens-co.html Fiji military government tightens control]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, DPA, 14 April 2009</ref>
On 31 July, President Iloilo, 88 years old and thought to be ill, retired after having served since 2000 through all the coups, except for one month in 2006 when Bainimarama gave himself Presidential powers. Iloilo was replaced by the Vice-President, [[Brigadier-General]] [[Epeli Nailatikau|Ratu Epeli Nailatikau]], a former military commander. Under the 1997 Constitution, the President was supposed to be appointed by the Great Council of Chiefs, but with the Constitution suspended, Bainimarama announced that a replacement would be appointed by himself and his Cabinet at a time suitable for the regime.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-07/28/content_11786348.htm Fiji's 88-year-old president retires], Xinhua, 28 July 2009</ref><ref name="Stuff.co.nz_2683048">{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/south-pacific/2683048/Fijis-president-quits |title=Fiji's president quits |author=Field, Michael |date=28 July 2009 |work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=18 September 2011}}</ref>
==Economy== As well as the rest of the world, Fiji had been influenced by the [[global financial crisis of 2008–2009]] before the constitutional crisis began. Fiji's foreign currency reserves had fallen by 1/3 during 2008 and, in February 2009, [[Standard and Poor's]] downgraded Fiji's long term credit rating from stable to negative.<ref name="SP">[http://www.michaelfield.org/S&P.htm Outlook On Fiji Revised To Negative On Rising External Pressures; ŒB/B Rating Affirmed]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Standard and Poor's, 27 February 2009</ref> Exports increased in 2008 and inflation declined; however, cashflow suffered from the global financial crisis and imports increased leading to a larger negative [[balance of trade]].<ref name ="SP" /><ref>[http://www.ftib.org.fj/uploaded_documents/Economic%20Review%20February%202009.pdf Economic Review]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Vol. 26, No. 02, Reserve Bank of Fiji, February 2009</ref>
After the constitutional crisis began, the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Fiji was removed from his position, as were all other people appointed to positions under the 1997 Constitution. The Reserve Bank quickly made several major moves, imposing currency exchange restrictions and devaluing the currency by 20% to benefit exporters and tourism.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=ajvPqV2sZP0U&refer=home Fiji Devalues Local Dollar 20 Percent, Central Bank Announces], James Regan, Bloomberg, 15 April 2009</ref> On 16 April, the Bank ordered Australian banks operating in Fiji to limit interest rates and institute [[microlending]] programs.<ref>[http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-business/fiji-tells-aussie-banks-to-cut-rates-20090416-a8n3.html Fiji tells Aussie banks to cut rates], Alison Bell, Sydney Morning Herald, 16 April 2009</ref> [[Standard and Poor's]] lowered Fiji's credit rating on 16 April, with short term credit falling to a C from a B rating.<ref>[http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=119355 Fiji's credit rating down], Fiji Times, 16 April 2009</ref> On 21 April, [[Moody's]] lowered Fiji's government bond, foreign currency bank deposit and foreign currency bond ratings, into [[junk bond]] status, stating "Political instability is weakening Fiji's long-term economic strength" among other reasons.<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20090421-718892.html Moody's Lowers Fiji's Ratings Amid Political Unrest], ''The Wall Street Journal'', 21 April 2009</ref>
In a move claimed to be aimed at cutting public corruption, Bainimarama announced "As a first up, from next week, all government vehicles being driven after hours will need to carry permits." Soldiers and police would be empowered to check for these permits.<ref name="Field"/>
As a cost-cutting measure, the mandatory retirement age for civil servants was reduced to 55, with 30 April 2009 set as the retirement day for any over that age.<ref name="NZ_Herald_10567012">{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10567012 |title=Fiji slashes retirement age in bid to cut costs |author=Young, Audrey |date=17 April 2009 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=18 September 2011}}</ref> Since 2007, the Fiji Teacher Association had been fighting the order to lower the retirement age from 60 to 55; the Public Service Association had later joined as a party to the lawsuit.<ref name="RNZI_45545">{{cite web |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=45545 |title=Fiji’s Teachers Association prepares for Supreme Court case over retirement at 55 |date=25 March 2009 |work=[[Radio New Zealand International]] |accessdate=18 September 2011}}</ref> Certain high-level positions were given a retirement age of 65, including the position of Commander of the Military Forces held by Bainimarama who will turn 55 three days before the decree goes into effect. The decree was expected to force the retirement of over 800 teachers and about 100 nurses. (Another 40 nurses had already moved overseas during 2009 before the decree.)<ref>[http://www.fijilive.com/news_new/index.php/news/show_news/15302 1000 Fiji civil servants to retire, say unions] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306024759/http://www.fijilive.com/news_new/index.php/news/show_news/15302 |date=6 March 2012 }}, Fiji Live, 17 April 2009</ref>
==Suppression of the Media==
Reports indicated that as part of the Emergency Regulation "a Ministry of Information officer and a plain-clothed policeman would be stationed in every newsroom".<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-04/10/content_11163772.htm Public emergency regulation in force in Fiji], Xinhua News Agency, 10 April 2009</ref> The Permanent Secretary of the Department of Information explained the policy, saying that media are to "refrain from publishing and broadcasting any news item that is negative in nature, relating to the assumption of executive authority on 10 April...and the subsequent appointments..."<ref>[http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=119353 We comply with regulations], ''Fiji Times'', 16 April 2009</ref> Immediately after the decree as a form of protest, [[Fiji One]] TV did not run its evening news program and the ''[[Fiji Times]]'' went to press with large blank spaces where censored articles were removed. The ''[[Fiji Sun]]'' announced that it would no longer run any political stories of any sort.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20090413/wl_asia_afp/fijipoliticscouppacific_20090413105609 'Deep concern' after Fiji throws out journalists]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, AFP, 13 April 2009</ref> The ''[[Daily Post (Fiji)|Fiji Daily Post]]'' mocked the restrictions, publishing stories under "Man gets on bus"<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090503120930/http://www.fijidailypost.com/news.php?section=1&fijidailynews=23081 Man gets on bus], Fiji Daily Post, 15 April 2009. Retrieved 1 June 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hj1m2WH2?url=http://www.fijidailypost.com/news.php?section=1&fijidailynews=23079 Archived] 22 June 2009.</ref> and "Breakfast as usual".<ref>[http://www.fijidailypost.com/news.php?section=1&fijidailynews=23081 Breakfast as usual] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503120930/http://www.fijidailypost.com/news.php?section=1&fijidailynews=23081 |date=3 May 2009 }}, Fiji Daily Post, 15 April 2009</ref><ref name="3_News_100012">{{cite web|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/News/InternationalNews/Fiji-newspaper-digs-at-interim-govt-with-lead-story-Man-gets-on-bus/tabid/417/articleID/100012/cat/61/Default.aspx |title=Fiji newspaper digs at interim govt with lead story: Man gets on bus |date=17 April 2009 |work=[[3 News]] |accessdate=18 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hj1mQz53?url=http://www.3news.co.nz/News/InternationalNews/Fiji-newspaper-digs-at-interim-govt-with-lead-story-Man-gets-on-bus/tabid/417/articleID/100012/cat/61/Default.aspx |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
On 13 April two of the last remaining foreign journalists in Fiji were called to Government House by the Ministry of Information. ABC Pacific Correspondent Sean Dorney was asked to voluntarily leave Fiji—which he refused citing his valid visa—and TV3 reporter Sia Aston's footage was confiscated by Fijian authorities. Both Dorney and Aston were deported from Fiji on 14 April, with Aston and TV3 cameraman Matt Smith banned from ever returning to Fiji, with the interim Government stating that all three had breached their visa conditions.<ref name=radionz1>[http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/stories/2009/04/14/1245aa006045 TV3 news pair banned from returning to Fiji] Radio New Zealand News, 14 April 2009 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222054828/http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/stories/2009/04/14/1245aa006045 |date=22 February 2012 }}</ref><ref name=stuff2>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/2338529/Journalists-most-welcome-to-Fiji |title=Journalists 'most welcome' to Fiji |date=16 April 2009 |work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=18 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hj1knhAL?url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/2338529/Journalists-most-welcome-to-Fiji |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> Edwin Nand, a local journalist for Fiji TV, was imprisoned for 36 hours after he interviewed Dorney.<ref name="RadioNZ">{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/south-pacific/2336132/Bainimarama-attacks-New-Zealand-govt |title=Bainimarama attacks New Zealand govt |author=Field, Michael |date=15 April 2009 |work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=18 September 2011}}</ref> Fijian Military spokesman Neumi Leweni stated that foreign journalists were welcome in Fiji, but must first apply and that "the invitation is decidedly conditional."<ref name=stuff2/> However, during an interview with [[Radio New Zealand]], Bainimarama said it was not necessary for their reporter to visit Fiji: "You just ask me the questions, I will give you the answers."<ref name= "RadioNZ"/> On 17 April, military spokesman Neumi Leweni said foreign media personnel would have to apply to his office for visas and approval would be "based on how they have reported about Fiji in the past, if they have, or on the undertaking that they will report accurately and responsibly."<ref name="Field"/>
Fijian media outlets and journalists have also come under government scrutiny. There were rumours of the imminent deportation of Anne Fussell, the publisher of the [[Fiji Times]] newspaper.<ref name=radionz1/> Three newspaper editors had been deported in the 14 months before the crisis.<ref>[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/business/story/0,28124,24973315-7582,00.html Media slams third Fiji Times deportation], ''The Australian'', 28 January 2009</ref> Fijian journalists working for international media outlets have also been called before the military to explain reports.<ref name=stuff2/>
The Government has also shut down two [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] [[Transmitter|FM transmitters]], meaning that both ABC and [[Radio New Zealand International]] are only available to Fiji via the [[shortwave]] service.<ref name=radionz2>{{cite web|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/stories/2009/04/15/1245aa0f4649 |title=Media in Fiji told to adopt 'journalism of hope' |date=17 April 2009 |work=[[Radio New Zealand]] |accessdate=18 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hj1lc1AS?url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/stories/2009/04/15/1245aa0f4649 |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> Internet cafes have also become a target because of independent news bloggers, with many having to shut down. Networks, software and archives are inspected by government officials, with Commodore Bainimarama saying that free speech "causes trouble" and must be curbed in order for the Government to carry out reforms.<ref>[http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1015570/Fiji-crackdown-intensifies Fiji crackdown intensifies], World News Australia, 15 April 2009</ref>
The [[Pacnews]] [[wire service]] announced they will no longer cover Fiji stories after police and censors required them to remove a story on the UN statements about the crisis.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/04/22/2550051.htm?section=justin Pacnews drops Fiji coverage after censorship], Campbell Cooney, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, 22 April 2009</ref> The announcement followed the detention of journalist [[Pita Ligaiula]], a writer for Pacnews and correspondent for the [[Australian Associated Press]], who was arrested by two police officers and an official for the Ministry of Information on 15 April 2009.<ref name=rnzi16>{{cite news |title=Another Fiji journalist detained over report|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=46010|work=[[Radio New Zealand International]]|date=16 April 2009 |accessdate=25 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090419094753/http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=46010| archivedate= 19 April 2009 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Matai Akauola, of the [[Pacific Islands News Association]], reported that one of Ligaiula's [[byline]]s may have violated Fiji's current media restrictions.<ref name=rnzi16/> Pacnews has announced that it has no plans to relocate from its headquarters in Suva, Fiji, to another country due to the restrictions on reporting Fijian domestic news.<ref name=rnzi23>{{cite news |title=Pacnews has no plans to quit Suva despite Fiji censorship |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=46140|work=[[Radio New Zealand International]]|date=23 April 2009 |accessdate=25 April 2009}}</ref>
==Local political reaction== The [[Soqosoqo Duavata ni Lewenivanua]] party declared that the suspension of the constitution was another coup.<ref>[http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=118913 It is another coup, says SDL party], Fiji Times Online, 11 April 2009</ref> The [[National Federation Party]] also condemned the President's actions. The [[Fiji Labour Party]] said that the country could not sustain a five-year wait for elections and urged elections to be called sooner.<ref>[http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=118911 Chaudhry wants quick return], Fiji Times Online, 11 April 2009</ref>
==International reaction== The UN Secretary General called for the "restoration of a legitimate government".<ref>[http://news.theage.com.au/breaking-news-world/un-chief-deplores-fiji-action-20090411-a35i.html UN chief 'deplores' Fiji action], The Age, 11 April 2009</ref> The U.S. spoke of "deep disappointment" and Australia called the situation "grave and unwelcome".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7994426.stm Fiji coup leader restored as PM], BBC News, 11 April 2009</ref> New Zealand's Foreign Minister referred to the situation as "a sorry recipe that has been tried by dictators in a number of other countries, always with tragic consequences."<ref name="TVNZ_2636849">{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/politics-news/mccully-slams-bainimarama-appointment-2636849 |title=McCully slams Fiji appointment |date=11 April 2009 |work=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]]/[[Reuters]] |accessdate=18 September 2011}}</ref> New Zealand Prime Minister [[John Key]] said that "the reality is that unless there is some miraculous turn around of events, Fiji is going to be suspended by the [Pacific Islands] forum in roughly two weeks," and that he would back immediate action. The forum's chair, [[Niue]]'s [[Premier of Niue|Premier]] [[Toke Talagi]], is also advocating immediate suspension.<ref name=stuff2/>
[[Samoa]]n Prime Minister [[Tuilaepa Sailele]] took a particularly strong stance, saying "But one day soon the puppets will grow a brain and see Frank for the evil puppeteer he really is. It is then the curtains will fall on Frank..The whole thing is a political charade and the whole world is watching. Nobody is fooled and no one is laughing. Frank is only fooling himself..Go put back on his military uniform or..maybe, he’d look better in a prison uniform."<ref name= "Field"/>
The [[United Nations Security Council]] issued a statement: "The members of the Security Council are deeply concerned about the situation in Fiji, where undemocratic decisions were made, including the abrogation of the constitution. The members of the Security Council express hopes that Fiji will make a steadfast advancement towards democracy and that fair elections will be held as soon as possible."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8009450.stm UN condemns military rule in Fiji], BBC, 21 April 2009</ref> The United Nations also said that it would not increase the number of Fijian police or soldiers involved in its peacekeeping operations, or deploy them on any future missions, although it would continue to use them in its existing operations.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-05/02/content_11296917.htm UN bars Fijian peacekeepers in future missions], Xinhua, 2 May 2009.</ref>
On 1 May, the [[Pacific Islands Forum]] suspended Fiji's membership as they had threatened months before if Fiji had not scheduled elections by that date.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-05/02/content_11297082.htm Fiji suspended from Pacific Islands Forum], Xinhua, 1 May 2009</ref> The 2009 suspension marked the first time that a country had been suspended from the Pacific Islands Forum in the history of the 38-year-old organization.<ref name=abc>{{cite news|title=Fiji isolated after election deadline expires |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/01/2558859.htm?section=justin |work=[[Australia Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=1 May 2009 |accessdate=3 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hj1mocYa?url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/01/2558859.htm?section=justin |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> As part of its suspensions, Fiji was also excluded from the discussions on the [[Pacific Agreement on Closer Economic Relations]] (PACER) and the [[Pacific Free Trade Agreement]] (PICTA).<ref>[http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asia/151269/ousted-fiji-accuses-neighbours-of-double-standards Ousted Fiji accuses neighbours of double standards], AFP, 8 August 2009</ref>
The [[Commonwealth of Nations]] suspended Fiji from its councils. In August, the Commonwealth gave Fiji until 1 September to announce scheduled elections to occur no later than October 2010. Failing that, Fiji would be "fully suspended" from the Commonwealth,<ref name="TVNZ_2881911">{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/fiji-given-september-ultimatum-2881911 |title=Fiji given September ultimatum |date=1 August 2009 |work=[[One News (New Zealand)|ONE News]]/[[Newstalk ZB]] |accessdate=18 September 2011}}</ref> a threat that was carried out when no such announcement was made.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8231717.stm Fiji Suspended from Commonwealth], BBC News, 1 September 2009</ref>
Australia and New Zealand suspended [[Diplomatic relations of Fiji|diplomatic relations]] in 2009. Full diplomatic relations were restored on 30 July 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2012/07/201273083010385875.html|title=Australia and NZ restore full ties with Fiji|website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref>

{{Redirect|Gun runner|the racehorse|Gun Runner (horse)}} [[Image:Gun pyre in Uhuru Gardens, Nairobi.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A tower of confiscated smuggled weapons about to be set ablaze in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]]]]
'''Arms trafficking''', also known as '''gunrunning''', is the trafficking of contraband [[weapon]]s and [[ammunition]]. What constitutes legal trade in firearms varies widely, depending on local and national laws.
The 1999 Report of the UN Panel of Governmental Experts on Small Arms provides a more refined and precise definition, which has become internationally accepted. This distinguishes between small arms (revolvers and self-loading pistols, rifles and [[carbine]]s, [[submachine gun]]s, [[assault rifle]]s, and light machine guns), which are weapons designed for personal use, and light weapons (heavy machine guns, hand-held under-barrel and mounted [[grenade launcher]]s, portable anti-aircraft guns, portable anti-tanks guns, [[recoilless rifle]]s, portable launchers of anti-aircraft missile systems, and mortars of calibres less than 100 mm), which are designed for use by several persons serving as a unit. Ammunition and explosives also form an integral part of small arms and light weapons used in conflict.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Greene |first=O. |title=Examining international responses to illicit arms trafficking |journal=Crime, Law & Social Change |year=2000 |volume=33 |url=http://www.criminology.fsu.edu/transcrime/articles/armstraffickingagreements.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323050427/https://www.criminology.fsu.edu/transcrime/articles/armstraffickingagreements.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-23 }}</ref>
==Impact==
===Areas=== Although arms trafficking is widespread in regions of political turmoil, it is not limited to such areas, and for example, in [[South Asia]], an estimated 63 million guns have been trafficked into India and Pakistan.<ref>{{cite news|work=The Daily Star|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/2006/05/30/d6053001107.htm|date= May 30, 2006 |title= Bangladesh turned into arms smuggling route; Experts critical of govt's indifference|author=Staff Correspondent}}</ref>
The suppression of gunrunning is one of the areas of increasing interest in the context of [[international law]]. Examples of past and current gunrunning include: * [[Iran–Contra affair]] * [[Larne gun-running]] * [[Provisional Irish Republican Army arms importation]]
In the United States, the term "[[Iron Pipeline]]" is sometimes used to describe [[Interstate Highway 95]] and its connector highways as a corridor for arms trafficking into New York City.<ref name=Enos>{{cite book|last=Enos|first=Sandra L.|editor=Gregg Lee Carter|title=Guns in American Society: An Encyclopedia of History, Politics, Culture, and the Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oD46JBOhMU0C&pg=PA440|accessdate=7 May 2015|year=2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9780313386701|pages=440–44|chapter=Iron Pipeline}}</ref>
===Market value=== The total value of the global arms market is estimated around $60 billion a year, with around $8 billion attributed to pistols, rifles, machine guns, and bullets.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Whitney, Craig R. |date=December 2012 |url=http://www.worldpolicy.org/journal/winter2012/ruling-arms |title=Ruling Arms |work=World Policy Journal}}</ref> The total illegal arms trade is harder to estimate, but the illicit [[small arms trade|small arms market]] has been estimated at 10–20% of the total global arms trade.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Schroeder, Matt |author2=Lamb, Guy |lastauthoramp=yes |date=2006 |url=https://fas.org/asmp/library/articles/SchroederLamb.pdf |title=The Illicit Arms Trade in Africa |work=African Analyst |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070221133132/http://www.fas.org/asmp/library/articles/SchroederLamb.pdf |archivedate=21 February 2007 |accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref>
===Notable arms dealers=== *[[Ali Fayad]] * [[Monzer al-Kassar]] * [[Pierre Beaumarchais]] * [[Viktor Bout]] * [[Samuel Cummings]] * [[Arcadi Gaydamak]] * [[Adnan Khashoggi]] * [[Leonid Minin]] * [[Sarkis Soghanalian]] * [[Dale Stoffel]] * [[Gerhard Mertins]] * [[John Nardi]] * [[Basil Zaharoff]] * [[Efraim Diveroli]]
==In popular culture==
===Film=== *''[[Lord of War]]'' (2005), a fictional crime [[war film]] in which [[Nicolas Cage]] plays an illegal arms dealer similar to the post-Soviet arms dealer [[Viktor Bout]]; the film was endorsed by [[Amnesty International]] for highlighting the arms trafficking by the international arms industry * ''Making a Killing: Inside the International Arms Trade'' (2006), a 15-minute documentary included in the two-Disc Special Edition DVD of ''[[Lord of War]]'' (2005).<ref>{{cite web|website=IMDb|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0778772/|title=Making a Killing: Inside the International Arms Trade}}</ref> Numerous other documentaries about arms trafficking are linked on this film's [[YouTube]] page.<ref>{{cite book|title=Making a Killing: Inside the International Arms Trade|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r0sC3CSp24E|publisher=YouTube}}</ref> *''[[Iron Man (2008 film)|Iron Man]]'' (2008), a superhero film in which based on the [[Marvel Comics]] character [[Iron Man|of the same name]], centering inventor Tony Stark ([[Robert Downey Jr.]]) discovers his company has been arms trafficking weapons of his own designs to criminals worldwide, and seeks to stop his corrupt executives and other employees by becoming the technologically advanced [[superhero]] Iron Man. *''[[War Dogs (2016 film)|War Dogs]]'' (2016), a black [[comedy-drama]] [[biographical film]] based on the true story of two young men, [[David Packouz]] and [[Efraim Diveroli]], who won a $300 million contract from the Pentagon to arm America's allies in Afghanistan who later became involved in arms trafficking. *[[Shot Caller (film)|Shot Caller]] (2017), a crime thriller in which recently paroled felon Jacob "Money" Harlon, is forced by his gang shot caller to orchestrate a major arms deal with an allied [[Sureno]] gang.
===Television=== *''[[Sons of Anarchy]]'', a FX-TV series about a fictional [[outlaw motorcycle club]] whose main source of income is trafficking arms to a variety of criminal enterprises domestically and internationally. *''[[Death in Paradise (TV series)|Death in Paradise]]'' Series 3, Episode 5, features [[Simon Shepherd]] as Jacob Doran, Saint Marie's Minister for Commerce, who is later found out by [[Humphrey Goodman]] to be a gunrunner. *''[[Jormungand (manga)|Jormungand]]'', an anime television series based on the [[manga]] series by Keitarō Takahashi, produced by [[White Fox]], which addresses the issue of arms trafficking in the [[Middle East]] and throughout the European continent. *''[[The Night Manager (miniseries)|The Night Manager]]'', a BBC miniseries where a former British soldier who is currently a night manager in hotels infiltrates the inner circle of an arms dealer.
===Video games=== *''[[Grand Theft Auto V]]'''s multiplayer platform, ''[[GTA Online]]'', has a [[downloadable content]] pack revolving around manufacturing and distributing illegal arms through smuggling operations and missions included in "Gunrunning". *[[Mafia III]], one of Lincoln Clay's underbosses, Haitian crime lord Cassandra, runs gun rackets.

{{Update|date=July 2015|inaccurate=yes}} {{Infobox government agency |agency_name = Australian Customs and Border Protection Service |type = Agency |nativename = |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = Australian Customs Flag 1988-2015.svg |logo_width = 150px |logo_caption = [[Australian Customs Flag]] |seal = Australian Customs and Border Protection Service (emblem).jpg |seal_width = 100px |seal_caption = |picture = |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = 22 May 2009{{citation|title=CA 9259: Australian Customs and Border Protection Service|url=http://naa12.naa.gov.au/scripts/SearchOld.asp?Number=CA+9259|publisher=National Archives of Australia|accessdate=30 December 2013}} |preceding1 = [[Australian Customs Service]] |dissolved = 1 July 2015 |superseding = [[Australian Border Force]] |jurisdiction = [[Government of Australia]] |headquarters = Customs House
Canberra |coordinates = {{coord|35|17|1|S|149|7|55|E|type:landmark_region:AU|display=inline}} |employees = 5,424 (at June 2014){{citation|url=http://www.apsc.gov.au/about-the-apsc/parliamentary/aps-statistical-bulletin/aps-statistical-bulletin-2013-14/main-features#aps|title=Main features:APS at a glance|date=2014|author=Australian Public Service Commission|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141005120746/http://www.apsc.gov.au/about-the-apsc/parliamentary/aps-statistical-bulletin/aps-statistical-bulletin-2013-14/main-features|archivedate=5 October 2014}} |budget = [[Australian dollar|A$]]1.09 billion (2011) |agency_type = [[Statutory authority]] |parent_agency = [[Department of Immigration and Border Protection]] (2013-2015)
[[Attorney-General's Department (Australia)|Attorney-General's Department]] (2009-2013) |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |keydocument1= |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }} The '''Australian Customs and Border Protection Service''' was the [[Government of Australia|Australian federal government]] agency responsible for managing the security and integrity of the Australian border. It facilitated the movement of legitimate international travellers and goods, whilst protecting the safety, security and commercial interests of Australians.{{sfn|Australian Customs and Border Protection Service|2011|p=X}} The Service was an agency under the [[Attorney-General's Department (Australia)|Attorney-General's Department]] from 2009 to 2013 and was then transferred to the newly formed [[Department of Immigration and Border Protection]] in 2013 until its transformation into the Border Force in 2015. The Australian Customs and Border Protection Service employed over 5,800 people around Australia and overseas and was headquartered in Canberra.{{sfn|Australian Customs and Border Protection Service|2011}} ==Agency role== The Service defined its role as follows: ''“Our role is complex and diverse and requires a very considered and increasingly targeted approach to conducting our business. If we do not manage our responsibilities effectively, the potential impacts… may negatively affect the Australian community, international travellers and trade relations both here and overseas”'' [http://www.customs.gov.au/webdata/minisites/annualreport1011/ceo_review.html CEO Review], Customs and Border Protection, 1 May 2012 The Service was Australia's predominant border control agency. From international travellers at airports, to overseas mail and trade brought in by sea, it was responsible for the continued safety and security of the people and goods that travel across Australia's borders.[http://www.customs.gov.au/site/page4222.asp About Us], Customs and Border Protection, 1 May 2012 [[Image:Australian Customs.jpg|thumb|An Offshore Patrol Vessel of the [[Customs Marine Unit]] docked in [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], [[Northern Territory]]]] In conjunction with the Australian Defence Force, the Service facilitated Australia's response to the detection and rescue of 'suspected irregular entry vessels' that smuggled people from South-East Asia into Australian waters.[http://www.bpc.gov.au Border Protection Command], 1 May 2012 The agency was also responsible for the discovery and apprehension of 'illegal foreign fishing vessels', the patrol of remote Australian and international waters, and aerial surveillance of Australia’s coastline.[http://www.bpc.gov.au/site/page5777.asp Maritime Security Threats], Border Protection Command, 1 May 2012 To achieve these functions, the Service operated its own air and sea patrol unit, the [[Customs Marine Unit (Australia)|Customs Marine Unit]]. The Service used an intelligence-led, risk-based approach to managing threats, focussing on specific targets that may pose a risk to the border.{{sfn|Australian Customs and Border Protection Service|2011|p=X}} This allowed the agency to plan coordinated responses, interventions and strategies with various other government agencies, including; [[Australian Crime Commission]], [[Australian Federal Police]], [[Attorney-General's Department (Australia)|Attorney-General’s Department]], [[Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (Australia)|Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry]], [[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]], [[Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Australia)|Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade]], [[Department of Immigration and Border Protection]] and the [[Department of Infrastructure and Regional Development#Office of Transport Security|Office of Transport Security]].[http://www.bpc.gov.au/site/page5603.asp Partner Agencies], Border Protection Command, 1 May 2012 ===Import and export control=== Customs controlled the import and export of goods to and from Australia, in particular the control of prohibited or restricted items, and the interception of illegal and potentially harmful goods such as drugs, weapons and computer games. Techniques used to target high-risk aircraft, vessels, cargo, postal items and travellers included using intelligence, computer-based profiling and analysis, [[Australian Customs Detector Dog Program|detector dogs]], [[Smartgate]], container X-ray facilities, closed-circuit television (CCTV) monitoring and other means. Customs officers at air and sea ports, in addition to performing basic immigration control (see below), assessed passengers [[Arrival card|arrival]] and [[departure card]]s, and had the authority to scan and search passenger baggage. Quarantine risk material could be referred to [[Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service]] officers. Goods arriving from overseas by post were cleared by Customs and AQIS officers before being released to [[Australia Post]] for delivery. Customs collected [[Goods and Services Tax (Australia)|goods and services tax]] (GST) on taxable goods imported into Australia. Customs administered the Tourist Refund Scheme (TRS) for tourists visiting Australia temporarily or Australian residents leaving the country, allowing them, under certain conditions, to claim a refund of the GST or [[Wine equalisation tax]] on items purchased in Australia.[http://www.customs.gov.au/site/page4646.asp Tourist Refund Scheme], Australian Customs and Border Protection Service, 1 May 2012 ===People smuggling=== The Service was the lead agency in the Australian government’s response to people-smuggling and often performed activities on behalf of other agencies including: * Monitoring Australian waters for potential people smuggling vessels * Intercepting boats carrying immigrants without valid visas with Bay Class vessels[http://www.customs.gov.au/webdata/resources/files/BayClassVesselsFactSheet.pdf Bay Class Vessels], Customs and Border Protection, 1 May 2012 * Transporting people found in vessels to Australian territory for immigration and quarantine assessment * Coordinating education and awareness campaigns overseas to deter people-smuggling activities ===Terrorism=== The Service operated under the 'National Counter-Terrorism Plan', which was a plan intended to mitigate any risk of terrorism in Australia. The Service worked in conjunction with other Australian Government departments to screen and target any potential threats moving across the border,{{sfn|Australian Customs and Border Protection Service|2011}} including: * Air and sea passengers * Cargo (sea, air and mail) * Maritime surveillance * Remote area patrols ===Illegal entry=== The Service was responsible for processing all travellers entering[http://www.customs.gov.au/site/page4443.asp Arriving Passengers], Customs and Border Protection, 1 May 2012 and leaving[http://www.customs.gov.au/site/page4725.asp Departing Travellers] the country. At the border, Service officers would check all passengers to ensure compliance with customs, immigration and quarantine requirements. The Service's purpose was to stop people without correct documentation or [[Electronic visas (Australia)|visas]] from entering the country. ===Controlled substances=== One of the largest areas of work undertaken by the Service was in relation to the importation of [[narcotics trafficking|narcotics]] and [[Precursor (chemistry)|precursor]] substances and the smuggling of illegal amounts of tobacco.{{sfn|Australian Customs and Border Protection Service|2011}} Examination techniques such as x-ray, trace detection technology and detector dogs were used to screen people, goods, mail, vessels and aircraft moving across Australia’s border. ===Objectionable material=== Australian law prohibits the importing of any material of an offensive or grotesque nature.{{sfn|Australian Customs and Border Protection Service|2011}} The Service worked to prevent the importation of material that was either refused classification by the Australian Classification Board, or was unclassified but would not be deemed as acceptable viewing by the [[Australian Classification Board]].[http://www.customs.gov.au/site/page4369.asp#e1070 Pornography and Objectionable Material], Australian Customs and Border Protection, 1 May 2012 This included material in [[electronic media|electronic form]] such as CDs or DVDs, computer hard drives and within electronic games. Prohibited material included: * Child pornography * Offensive or sexualised violence * Terrorist material * Drug use ===Illegal foreign fishing=== The Service was the lead agency coordinating regular patrol (both aerial surveillance and on-water) of Australia's 'Exclusive Economic Zone' to detect and deter any foreign fishing vessels.[http://www.customs.gov.au/webdata/resources/files/FS_Heard_Is_Mcdonald_Is1.pdf Patagonian Tooth Fish Factsheet], Australian Customs and Border Protection, 1 May 2012 Along with dedicated in-country education programs designed to deter people from undertaking illegal fishing,{{sfn|Australian Customs and Border Protection Service|2011}} the Service's work saw a continual decline in the rates of foreign fishing vessels entering the EEZ. ==History== ===Establishment=== The Australian Customs and Border Protection Service had its origins in the [[Department of Trade and Customs (Australia)|Department of Trade and Customs]], established at [[Federation of Australia|federation]] in 1901. The organisation was restructured several times since, including becoming the [[Department of Customs and Excise]] in 1958 and then briefly the [[Department of Police and Customs]] in 1975.{{sfn|Bannon|2007|p=12}} Later that same year, the Bureau of Customs was established, which remained the Australian Government's customs agency until 1985 when the Australian Customs Service was established.{{sfn|Bannon|2007|p=12}} In December 2008 then [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[Kevin Rudd]] announced that the Australian Government would be augmenting, re-tasking and renaming the Australian Customs Service to create the new Australian Customs and Border Protection Service.{{citation|url=http://pmtranscripts.dpmc.gov.au/browse.php?did=16289|title=The First National Security Statement to the Parliament Address by the Prime Minister of Australia The Hon. Kevin Rudd MP|date=4 December 2008|first=Kevin|last=Rudd|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230025339/http://pmtranscripts.dpmc.gov.au/browse.php?did=16289|archivedate=30 December 2013}} Royal assent was given to the changes on 22 May 2009 and the Australian Customs and Border Protection Service was established. ===Australian Border Force=== In 2015, the Australian Government announced changes to the Immigration and Border Protection portfolio in relation to future border protection arrangements. From 1 July 2015, the Department of Immigration and Border Protection and the Australian Customs and Border Protection Service were consolidated into a single Department of Immigration and Border Protection. At this time, the [[Australian Border Force]], a single frontline operational border agency, was established within the department. The Australian Border Force draws together the operational border, investigations, compliance, detention and enforcement functions of the two existing agencies. Policy, regulatory and corporate functions will combine within the broader department.{{refn|For more information about the changes, read the [http://www.minister.immi.gov.au/media/sm/2014/sm214247.htm Minister for Immigration and Border Protection's speech] announcing the new arrangements on 9 May 2014 and the [http://www.customs.gov.au/webdata/resources/files/Australian-Border-Force.pdf Australian Border Force booklet].|group=Note}} ==Agency statistics== When it existed, each week the Service would:{{sfn|Australian Customs and Border Protection Service|2011|loc=front pages}} ===Clear=== * 268,000 air passengers arriving in Australia * 1,620 international flights * 260 ships arriving in Australian ports from overseas * 14 overseas smallcraft * 24,600 export entries * 268,700 air way bills * 48,500 sea cargo manifest lines ===Patrol=== * Three million square nautical miles including: ** Australia's coastline and seas, including the Southern Ocean and Northern waters ** airports ** sea ports ** mail centres ===Inspect=== * 2000 sea cargo containers * 29,500 air cargo consignments * 776,000 letters * 405,500 parcels from overseas ===Collect=== * $188 million in revenue from various sources, for Customs and Border Protection and on behalf of other agencies ==See also== {{portal|Australia}} * [[Australian Border Force]] * [[Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service]] * [http://archiv.uni-nke.hu/uploads/media_items/aarms-2017-1-07-besenyo.original.pdf Fences and
